messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 45 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Exact Algorithms for Clustered Planarity with Linear Saturators

Paper Abstract: Abstract We study Clustered Planarity with Linear Saturators, which is the problem of augmenting an nùëõn-vertex planar graph whose vertices are partitioned into independent sets (called clusters) with paths‚Äîone for each cluster‚Äîthat connect all the vertices in each cluster while maintaining planarity. We show that the problem can be solved in time 2ùí™‚Äã(n)superscript2ùí™ùëõ2^{\mathcal{O}(n)} for both the variable and fixed embedding case. Moreover, we show that it can be solved in subexponential time 2ùí™‚Äã(n‚Äãlog‚Å°n)superscript2ùí™ùëõùëõ2^{\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{n}\log n)} in the fixed embedding case if additionally the input graph is connected. The latter time complexity is tight under the Exponential-Time Hypothesis. We also show that nùëõn can be replaced with the vertex cover number of the input graph by providing a linear (resp. polynomial) kernel for the variable-embedding (resp. fixed-embedding) case; these results contrast the \NP-hardness of the problem on graphs of bounded treewidth (and even on trees). Finally, we complement known lower bounds for the problem by showing that Clustered Planarity with Linear Saturators is \NP-hard even when the number of clusters is at most 333, thus excluding the algorithmic use of the number of clusters as a parameter.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 45 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 45"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Compatible connectivity augmentation of planar disconnected graphs",
        "Clustered planarity with pipes",
        "Beyond clustered planar graphs",
        "Intersection-link representations of graphs",
        "2-Level quasi-planarity or how caterpillars climb (SPQR-)trees",
        "Relaxing the constraints of clustered planarity",
        "The importance of being proper: (in clustered-level planarity and T-level planarity)",
        "Planarity of overlapping clusterings including unions of two partitions",
        "Simultaneous embeddability of two partitions",
        "Synchronized planarity with applications to constrained planarity problems",
        "A new perspective on clustered planarity as a combinatorial embedding problem",
        "Visual analysis of controversy in user-generated encyclopedias",
        "Advances on testing c-planarity of embedded flat clustered graphs",
        "Inserting a vertex into a planar graph",
        "Inserting multiple edges into a planar graph",
        "Shrinking the search space for clustered planarity",
        "Clustered planarity",
        "C-planarity of c-connected clustered graphs",
        "Clustered planarity = flat clustered planarity",
        "Subexponential-time and FPT algorithms for embedded flat clustered planarity",
        "C-planarity testing of embedded clustered graphs with bounded dual carving-width",
        "Efficient c-planarity testing for embedded flat clustered graphs with small faces",
        "Overlapping cluster planarity",
        "Catalan structures and dynamic programming in h-minor-free graphs",
        "Planarity for clustered graphs",
        "A new approximation algorithm for the planar augmentation problem",
        "Kernelization: Theory of Parameterized Preprocessing",
        "Clustered level planarity",
        "Clustered planarity testing revisited",
        "Atomic embeddability, clustered planarity, and thickenability",
        "C-planarity of extrovert clustered graphs",
        "Advances in c-planarity testing of clustered graphs",
        "Which problems have strongly exponential complexity?",
        "Clustered planarity: Embedded clustered graphs with two-component clusters",
        "Clustered planarity: Clusters with few outgoing edges",
        "Clustered planarity: Small clusters in cycles and eulerian graphs",
        "Hypergraph planarity and the complexity of drawing venn diagrams",
        "A general framework for visualizing abstract objects and relations",
        "Planar graph augmentation problems (extended abstract)",
        "Hierarchical planarity testing algorithms",
        "A separator theorem for planar graphs",
        "Visual data mining of graph based data",
        "Exploring the combination of software visualization and data clustering in the software architecture recovery process",
        "Alpha-algorithms for incremental planarity testing (preliminary version)",
        "A note on obstructions to clustered planarity"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 45 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Exact Algorithms for Clustered Planarity with Linear Saturators, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
